hypothesis.name: Optimal Mid-Tilt
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt angle around 30° is often optimal for solar panels in temperate regions, balancing sunlight exposure throughout the day.

hypothesis.name: High Azimuth Exploration
hypothesis.rationale: Exploring a high azimuth angle (270°) may capture late afternoon sunlight, which can be beneficial for energy production.

hypothesis.name: Low Tilt for High Latitude
hypothesis.rationale: At higher latitudes, a lower tilt angle (10°) can help maximize energy capture during summer months when the sun is high.

hypothesis.name: Balanced Capacity Ratio
hypothesis.rationale: A DC to AC ratio of 1.5 can optimize energy conversion efficiency, especially in systems with higher capacity.

hypothesis.name: Morning Sun Focus
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of 40° and azimuth of 60° can optimize energy capture during morning hours, which is crucial for daily energy production.

hypothesis.name: High Tilt Exploration
hypothesis.rationale: Exploring higher tilt angles (around 70°) has shown promising results in maximizing energy output.

hypothesis.name: Afternoon Sun Capture
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of 60° and azimuth of 200° may optimize energy capture during the afternoon, building on previous successful configurations.

hypothesis.name: Moderate Tilt and Capacity
hypothesis.rationale: A moderate tilt of 40° with a system capacity of 10 kW can balance energy production and efficiency.

hypothesis.name: Low Capacity with High Tilt
hypothesis.rationale: Testing a lower capacity (5 kW) with a high tilt (75°) may yield interesting results, as seen in previous high-output configurations.

hypothesis.name: Exploring Near-Optimal Angles
hypothesis.rationale: A tilt of 68° and azimuth of 175° is close to previously successful configurations and may yield high energy output.

hypothesis.name: High Tilt and Optimal Azimuth
hypothesis.rationale: Continuing to explore high tilt angles (around 70u00b0) with an azimuth of 180u00b0 has shown consistent high energy outputs.

hypothesis.rationale: Testing a tilt of 80u00b0 with an azimuth of 190u00b0 may further enhance energy capture, building on previous successful configurations.
